Analysis

Masking Mao's legacy and diplomacy in Diaoyu

Rohan Banerjee looks at how the legacy of Mao Zedong has had a detrimental effect on China and its revolutionary nostalgia in the Diaoyu crisis (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Houbazur via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Coalition has failed to rule competently

We are about half way through the government's five year term in Parliament

Sandy's electoral effect hard to gauge

Last week, Mitt Romney and Barack Obama were put to the test as Hurricane Sandy swept across the US (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Talk Radio News Service)

Government right to cut aid to India

Amidst the fanfare surrounding the recent US Presidential election, an announcement made by Justine Greening, our minister for International Development, slipped under the radar in the past week (Thumbnail credit George Osborne and Indian Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee (Photo credit: HM Treasury))

Foreign policy: the crucial divide

By James Bithell

Since the early 1990's, the US has been a hyper-power, the single most powerful actor on the international scene (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Joint Base Lewis McChord)

Obama for President

When Barack Obama became President four years ago he, in an instant, changed everything

Why Obama deserves a second term

It is agonisingly close. As Election Day approaches in America, Barack Obama and Mitt Romney are neck-and-neck in the opinion polls. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: davemakkar)

A House divided against itself

When Abraham Lincoln delivered his famous line, "A house divided against itself cannot stand" in 1858, he was referring to how American society was becoming so polarised by the conflict between the federal government and the individual states that the whole country was under threat (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Stijn Vogels)

If Obama could not change politics, who can?

'Hope'. 'Change'. 'Can we fix it?' met by ecstatic cries of 'YES WE CAN!' Such was the dizzying heights of four years ago. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Anthony Baker)

Fighting the taboo of mental illness

On 29th October Ed Miliband called for a culture change in the way we think about mental health issues in a speech at the Royal College of Psychiatrists, his first since the Labour Party Conference (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Cabinet Office)

Is it all about the economy?

"It's all about the economy, stupid." The slogan which swept Bill Clinton into the Oval Office has never rung truer than in the 2012 US Presidential Elections (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: World Affairs Council of Philadelphia)

Salmond may be punished for deceit over Europe

Neil Johnston analyses how this latest revelation could have damaging consequences on Alex Salmond's independence campaign (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Scottish Government via Flickr Creative Commons)

Romney's comments highlight unchanging inequality

Gender inequality is still a real problem and people need to wake up to it, says Rosie Shields (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: davelawrence8)

Lack of flak for Lib Dems is concerning

It is often said that if a government is not being criticised it isn't doing its job properly. Here Adam Highland argues that the lack of criticism coming the way of the Lib Dems is cause for concern (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Liberal Democrats via Flickr Creative Commons)

Stewart bests Reilly in parallel US election debate

The American election season is finally in full swing. Yes, despite what a year of Republican preliminary debates would have you think, the election season proper has just kicked off. (Thumbnail credit Bill O'Reilly (Photocredit: justinhoch))

Spinning themselves out of power

In the two years of coalition rule, the government's policies have been under the spotlight. Here though, Sam Shepherd argues that PR, not policy, has been the government's main flaw (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: UK in France)

Labour Conference: Unimpressive

Out of power and short of policies, the Labour Party's Conference 2012 proved to be a decidedly horizontal affair (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: The Labour Party)

The West must look at Syria differently

The way the debate on Syria is portrayed in the West is overly simplistic and thus unhelpful. Ignoring the concerns of other countries is dangerous because they are raising legitimate problems (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: FreedomHouse2)

History is not the solution to Afghanistan

The war in Afghanistan will not be 'Obama's Vietnam.' Afghanistan will not shadow his presidency as Vietnam did for Lyndon B. Johnson's. The analogy is a simplistic reading of past and a rather vast misconstruction of the present (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: The US Army)

Romney scores big win in first Presidential debate

Until last night the US election looked to be a forgone conclusion. The first debate between Governor Romney and President Obama has changed that. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Talk Radio News Service)

The Queen's intervention concerns more than just Abu Hamza

Hussein Kesvani analyses what we can learn from the Queen's intervention in the case of Abu Hamza (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Michael Gwyther-Jones via Flickr Creative Commons)

Boris's "Boris-ness" is a winning strategy

Josh Boswell argues that London Mayor Boris Johnson has the right recipe for success on a national scale (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: BackBoris2012 via Flickr Creative Commons)

Olympic spirit could quash Salmond's independence hopes

With the Olympics over there is already talk of the legacy the Games will leave behind. Of course there is the sporting legacy but they will hopefully leave another legacy: in uniting Britain (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Scottish Government)

Sports plans risk having the wrong effect

David Cameron has said that compulsory competitive team sports for primary school children will be included in a revised curriculum this autumn (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: lets.book)

UK should have boycotted Sri Lanka conference

Last week delegates from nineteen countries, including our own and America, attended Sri Lanka's 2012 Defence Seminar (Thumbnail credit The Sri Lankan Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa (Photo credit: Commonwealth Secretariat))

Romney wrong to choose Ryan

On Saturday Mitt Romney announced Wisconsin Congressman Paul Ryan as his Vice-Presidential nominee and the running mate with whom he will attempt to prevent President Obama serving a second term (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: mnassal)

Lords maths recommendations should go further

With the House of Lords recommending changes to the way maths is taught, Tom Lubek looks at whether these recommendations go far enough (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: edbrambley)

Miliband must seize chance to set out vision

In the last PMQs before the summer recess, Labour leader Ed Miliband was on buoyant form (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: bisgovuk)

Labour wrong to support military schools

Labour has suggested a military school could be set up in every region of England in order to raise aspirations in poor areas (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Defence Images)

Banking damaged again by LIBOR scandal

The LIBOR scandal is likely to further erode the public's respect for and trust in the banking sector (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: World Economic Forum)
